title.narrative: Youth for Social Harmony in th

description.narrative: The reform agenda is able to benefit the communities in the Fergana Valley in an inclusive manner, which improves community resilience and harmony, and the ability of the population to benefit from the reforms.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Output Indicator 1.1. Number of public initiatives and projects regarding most urgent needs of regional development at local level, proposed and promoted by youth for public discussions in mass media. Indicator 1.2. Number of initiatives discussed with local administrations and officials on the round tables organized by local youth activists. • Number of initiatives, discussed via TV or on-line broadcasted round tables. Indicator 1.3. The rate of successful completion of the trainings delivered to public servants at three districts of Ferghana valley.

comment.narrative: 1.1. 20 initiatives announced or exposed for public discussion. 1.2. 10 initiatives are discussed on round tables. 5 initiatives are discussed via on-line or tv broadcasted round tables. 1.3. Above 75% of training participants-public servants from three districts of Fergana region have successfully completed each of the training courses.

1.1. 1) Project supported the Initiative of the newly established Youth Parliament of Uzbekistan and set up an on-line meeting with the UNDP RR Ms. Matilda Dimovska on October 8, 2020 (75 participants). As the result of the on-line session the project managed to: - raise awareness of members of Youth Parliament on specific activities and mandates of UN agencies in Uzbekistan; - encourage members of Youth Parliament to take part in various outreach events/campaigns organized by UN agencies; - motivate members of Youth Parliament to work further to tackle development issues in Uzbekistan to leave no one behind.
2) Within the framework of the RRs mission to the Fergana Valley (Fergana, Namangan, Margilan) on October 28-30, the following public discussions were held, (270-300 participants in total): - UN and youth - Youth and local government - Youth and IT (at the IT park, Margilan), launch of the Technovation Girls Fergana programme and JustStart start-up accelerator.
1.2. 1) In cooperation with the National Partner Youth Affairs Agency of Uzbekistan project assisted in preparation and participation of candidates from government bodies and NGOs in the regional component of the on-line consultations on Prevention of Violent Extremism in Central Asia (16-22-23 October - 63 participants, 26 November 2020 - 175 participants). Particularly, the project communicated with the Institute for Research of the youth problems and training prospective personnel at the academy of Public Administration under the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, Institute for Strategic and Regional Studies under the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, General Prosecutors Office, Youth Union, Center for Studying Regional Threats. During the cooperation there were discussed suggestions by the youth and expert circles of Uzbekistan as well as there were drafted thematical papers by the participants. All in all, UNDP assisted in participation of 15 young activists and 3 experts in Regional on-line consultations. (20 participants from Uzbekistan)
2) Within the framework of the Second Republican Forum of Volunteer on 5 December (252 participants), a decision was made and the establishment of the Association of Volunteers of Uzbekistan (NGO) was announced.
1.3. According to the Project Document of the Joint Program, training programs for civil servants are being implemented by other partner UN agencies - UNODC, UNESCO.
UNDP is conducting 2 research activities targeting civil servants. 1) Youth needs assessment (Conflict analysis) to collect data on vulnerabilities and gain insight into barriers that hamper their participation in various spheres of life. The results of the analysis will be obtained in 2021 and discussed with the Government of Uzbekistan and administrations of the Ferghana, Andijan and Namangan regions. The study will inform all project components and interventions and will serve to identify agents of peace in pilot communities, who can actively participate in designing, implementing and monitoring activities. The results of the study would be used to identify and/or adjust the baselines and indicators of activities, and develop new workplans and strategies for furthers phases of support from PBF and UN country team.
2) Review of the legal framework to ensure that the local administrations implement their functions in line with human rights standards. Comparing the results of the expertise with the best international practices and the results of focus group discussions with the public service clients – and specifically with youth, the key priority directions of further improvement of the legislative base will be proposed. Specific focus will be put on the performing behavioral analysis of the regulative documents, instructions and laws with the aim to identify the norms which provoke violation of human rights and delivery of low-quality public services, especially those that may be identified in the conflict analysis and youth focus group discussions conducted as part of this project. This activity will therefore directly complement Activity 1.3.5, which is geared towards building skills and approaches of public administrators, by helping address structural issues within the legal framework that may cause human rights violations and lead to grievances, especially among young men and women in the first place.

1.1.At least 25% of project beneficiaries display improvements in attitudes and perceptions 65%. 1.2 At least 2 decision/resolution of one of the khokimiyats from Ferghana region, including 1 based on young women initiative 1.3.15 initiatives, at least 5 that are led by young women, are sustained 6 months after the project termination through local state budgets or other sources of funding. Increment of satisfaction rate increased on 25 percentage points during the project implementation period. 1.4.The project has created the demand within the community and duty bearers to sustain and utilize dialogue platforms created by the project without the direct involvement of RUNO engagement.

1.1 - Suitable channels for conducting an on-line survey were selected: Google forms and U-report. About 3,150 people took part in the survey and 32% of respondents were female. - According to the last on-line survey conducted among 398 beneficiaries of the programme asking them ‘How has your participation in the programme activities changed your life?’, almost 20% of respondents indicated that the programme interventions positively impacted their career choices and perspectives, 25% of respondents stated that they enhanced their knowledge and capacities as civil servants since they went through the training programme, 8% reported that they were enrolled in the universities, and the same proportion of respondents found new jobs. The share of respondents enrolled in the universities abroad and those launched their businesses equals 6% each. 23 young men and women created their mobile applications, and 17 programme participants became grant holders for commencing their social and entrepreneurial projects. - 43 (26F/17M) schoolteachers, psychologists and sports coaches increased their capacity to positively influence on the policy of local administrations and launched a youth life skills training program in 21 schools to build the resilience of more than 418 school students (202 girls/216 boys) in the Fergana Valley.
1.2 - One Memorandum of Understanding developed between the Youth Affairs Agency and the Department of Justice on support to legal clinics in the Fergana Valley.
1.3 - The project demonstrated alternative mechanisms of youth capacity by conducting activities and implementing initiatives such as JustStart start-up accelerator (268: 92F/176M), Y-Fikri youth public discussions platform (301: 216F/85M), Leadership Summer camp (84: 37F/47M), Technovation Girls programme (100 F), hackathons, Model UN Conference (150), Voice of Girls (50 F), Community Policing and Youth Crime Prevention Forum (30), International Youth forum, Second International Volunteers Forum. Participants of those initiatives established a network to communicate and support each other by sharing information on development opportunities for the young people in the country and abroad. - By promoting a culture of volunteering, the project helped civil society to act and contribute to drafting the regulations. - The project empowered young people and civil society to solve local communities pressing infrastructural and social needs through the development of various Mob Apps, small business projects. - Experts from Anticorruption Agency in collaboration with the project team created an environment among civil servants and university and school students petulant to corruption.
1.4 - Several events including the international conference The role of youth in countering radicalism, extremism and terrorism on February 18, 2021; the World Conference on Youth Rights Involving Youth in Global Action on August 12-13, 2021; Youth Forum 2021 on December 18-21 were conducted by the national partners engaging the youth community in the country, where the joint programme provided indirect technical assistance.
